Table 4 Entry Amount of phenol (g) sodium formate (g) Phenol conversion (%) Efficiency (%) C=O:C-OH Selectivity (%) C=O:C-OH 1 1 0.5 30 30:0 99:0 2 0.7 0.5 35 35:0 99:0 3 0.5 0.5 40 40:0 99:0 4 0.2 0.5 60 45;15 70:25 5 0.1 0.5 99 60:40 60:40 6 0.1 0.2 15 15:0 99:0 7 0.1 0.3 55 50:5 85:15 8 0.1 0.4 65 55:10 80:20 Reaction condition: 0.05g of Pd10%@KIT-5/350in 10 ml double distilled water at 40 °C In situ hydrogenation of phenol using sodium formate in an aqueous medium on unmodified palladium catalysts supported on KIT-5: Investigation of calcination temperature effect Ali Yazdani Investigation Resources Formal analysis Data curation Writing – original draft Alireza Najafi Chermahini Conceptualization Validation Resources Writing – review & editing Supervision ⁎ Marzieh Esmaeilzadeh Khabazi Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Department of Chemistry, Isfahan University of Technology, Isfahan 84154-83111, Iran Department of Chemistry Isfahan University of Technology Isfahan 84154-83111 Iran Department of Chemistry, Isfahan University of Technology, Isfahan 84154-83111, Iran ⁎ Corresponding author. In this research, in situ hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanone and cyclohexanol mixture (KA oil) in aqueous medium using sodium formate as the hydrogen source is studied by using Pd catalysts supported on mesoporous KIT-5. The effect of calcination temprature of catalysts as well as reaction temperature, time, catalyst types, the amount of initial phenol and sodium formate, which are the most effective factors for phenol conversion, were investigated and the optimum values are reported. The Pd10%@KIT-5/350 catalyst (calcined at 350°C) exhibited as the most effective catalyst. Using this catalyst, the best results were gained at 40°C and a reaction time of 6 h, the optimal ratio of phenol: catalyst 0.1:0.05 with 0.5 g sodium formate. Under these conditions, 99% phenol conversion was obtained. Pd10%@KIT-5/350 as the most effective catalyst was successfully regenerated by centrifugation and filtration after reaction and reused in four consecutive cycles. The results showed that the calcination temperature in the preparation of Pd@KIT-5 catalysts has an important role in the hydrogenation reaction of phenol. The studies in this research showed that the higher the calcination temperature, the lower the percentage of phenol conversion, but the selectivity of the catalyst for the production of cyclohexanone increases. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Phenol hydrogenation KA oil Cyclohexanol Cyclohexanone Pd@KIT-5 catalysts Sodium formate 1 Introduction The hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanone and cyclohexanol (known as KA oil) is one of the important reactions which studied broadly. This mixture that called (KA oil) is one of the main raw materials for the preparation of adipic acid and caprolactam used to prepare nylon 6, nylon 66 and polyamide resins [1–3]. KA oil can be produced from the oxidation of cyclohexane or hydrogenation of phenol [4–11]. Hydrogenation of phenol has traditionally been carried out in the gas phase with supported Pd and Pt catalysts as the most efficient method. Although harsh conditions, such as high temperatures, are required [12]. Therefore, researchers trying to find mild conditions for phenol hydrogenation in an aqueous phase which saves energy and costs and can be carried out at lower temperatures [13]. Phenol hydrogenation to cyclohexanone can be accomplished in a one-step or a two-step process. In the two-step process, phenol is first hydrogenated to cyclohexanol and followed by conversion of alcohol to cyclohexanone, which may be different under the influence of various catalysts [14,15]. In the two-step process, cyclohexanone and cyclohexanol are produced, which means that the selectivity for phenol hydrogenation is decreased, but the percentage of conversion of phenol to products is more significant than the one-step process [16]. On the other hand, one-step phenol hydrogenation has been interested due to its economic aspects such as simplicity, saving energy, and reducing waste [17]. Usually, the organic compounds solubility is the critical factor for the efficiency of chemical reactions achieved in aqueous media. Water is known as the most plentiful, cheapest, safest and most environmentally friendly solvent in nature, which is one of the most important research topics in green chemistry to study organic reactions in/on water [18,19]. Phenol is fully soluble in water at temperatures > 66°C but, the products of phenol reduction such as KA oil are insoluble in water under the reaction conditions, so the phenol hydrogenation could be completed in the aqueous phase at a low temperature [20]. Phenol hydrogenation by using hydrogen as the reducing agent has been extensively studied [21–24], however, hydrogen is dangerous, expensive, and has certain constraints for storage and transportation. Therefore, there is an effort to find sustainable sources such as methanol, formic acid, and, sodium or potassium formate, to supply the needed hydrogen for phenol hydrogenation. Recent studies on the hydrogenation of phenol have used sodium formate as a hydrogen source. They have used various catalysts in the field, most of which have been used in palladium metal research [25]. The use of sodium formate as a hydrogen donor on Pd/C was carried out under microwave irradiation, which was complete conversion to phenol at 80°C, but when subjected to regular heating at 80°C even for 5 h, the conversion rate was very low. In addition to microwave irradiation, Sasson et al. used Pd/C for phenol hydrogenation as a catalyst in the open atmosphere under reflux conditions. They reported a high conversion rate of phenol at 90°C for 6 h [12]. The activity of a catalyst may be affected by many factors such as active site (metal) loading and its dispersion, active site and support type, calcination temperature, calcination time, and calcination atmosphere. Among them, the calcination temperature is an important factor for catalyst synthesis in the formation of crystalline phase, dispersion state, the nature of active sites, and the pore diameter of supports, the particle size and the acid base properties of catalysts [26–29]. Many studies have been published dealing with the effect of calcination temperature on the activity and properties of Pd catalysts. Narayanan and Krishna studied the effect of calcination temperature of Pd/hydrotalcite catalysts on hydrogenation of phenol and found the best phenol conversion observed for the catalysts dried at 373 K [30]. Hong et al. synthesized mesoporous Pd-Al composites and used in succinic acid hydrogenation [31]. According to their results the catalytic activity was related to calcination temperature and the best succinic acid conversion and butyrolacton yield observed for the catalysts calcined at 450°C. Díaz et al. studied phenol hydrogenation in aqueous media over Pd/C catalysts. They found that the best phenol conversion and cyclohexanol yield obtained by using the catalyst calcined at 250°C [32]. This research was aimed to prepare several catalysts based on Pd metal on KIT-5 as support with different percentages of Pd and different calcination temperatures. The reaction conditions for in situ hydrogenation reaction of phenol using sodium formate as a hydrogen source were studied in the presence of prepared catalysts. Formic acid and its salts as derivatives of biomass have been suggested as a safe and large volume source for hydrogen production [33–35]. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Characterization and instrumentation Infrared Spectra for all compounds were recorded by the Bruker Tensor 27 FT-IR using KBr; the wavenumber unit is cm−1. To confirm cyclohexanone and cyclohexanol, an Agilent 5975C GC-MS chromatography device equipped with HP5 capillary column, was used. Also, to calculate the efficiency of cyclohexanone and cyclohexanol and the percentage of phenol conversion, gas chromatography (GC) model GC-2552 (Teifgostar Faraz, Iran) and SPBTM-5 capillary column (30 m 0.25 mm /0 0.25 μm) equipped with a flame ionization detector was used. X-ray diffraction patterns for all samples were prepared with Asevware XDM-300 using Ni-filtered Cu Ka (K= 0.15406 nm) radiation. The surface area of the samples was measured by the BET method by Belsorp mini II device with adsorption of liquid nitrogen (77 K) at a pressure of 0.98 = P/P°. Before the measurement, all materials were degassed at 120 °C for 4 h. FE-SEM and EDX analysis were performed using FEI Quanta FEG 450 device. Transmission electronic microscopy (TEM) images were obtained using an FEI Tecnai G2 apparatus. EBA 20 Hettich centrifuge at 7000 rpm was used to separate the catalyst from the reaction mixture. 2.2 Reagents and materials All materials were used from Merck, and Sigma Aldrich without purification. 2.3 Preparation of silicate substrate KIT-5 The synthetic procedure adopted for the KIT-5 was based on the formerly published report. Briefly, to a solution containing 5.00 g of neutral pluronic polymer surfactant F127 and 10.5g of concerted HCl in 240 mL double distilled water, 24.0 g of tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS) was added under vigorous stirring at 40°C for 24 h. Then, to make the mesostructured product, the mixture was heated at 100°C for 24 h and kept under static conditions. The obtained white solid was then separated and dried in the oven at 100°C overnight without any purification. Finally, the product was calcined at 550°C for 6 h to remove the surfactant template [36]. 2.4 Preparation of catalysts To prepare the catalysts, palladium metal was supported on the KIT-5 substrate by impregnation method. Palladium chloride salt was used to make the catalyst, dissolved by hydrochloric acid in 20 mL of water. The specified amount of KIT-5 was dispersed in 30 mL water, and the metal solution was added and heated under stirring for 24 h. Subsequently, the beaker containing the salt and the substrate was transferred to the oven at 80°C to drying the sample. Finally, the catalysts were calcined in the furnace for 5 h at 150°C, 350°C, 550°C and 700°C. Different percentages of metal salts are used and calcined at different temperatures to investigate phenol hydrogenation reaction. 2.5 Phenol hydrogenation: general procedure The phenol hydrogenation reaction was performed in a 50 mL inner Teflon line steel autoclave with 0.1 g of phenol, 0.5 g of sodium formate, 0.05 g of pd@KIT-5/350 and 10 mL of deionized water were carried out at 40°C for 6 h. After completion of the reaction, autoclave was cooled, and the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by centrifugation The organic layer was extracted by ethyl acetate dried with calcium chloride and analysed using gas chromatography. A GC (GC-2552, TGF Co.) was equipped with a capillary HP5 column (30.0m × 0.25mm × 0.25 μm) and a flame ionization detector (FID) was used to determination of products by addition of biphenyl as the internal standard. Also, GC–MS instrument system (Agilent, 7890A) was used to confirm the synthesis of products. After each reaction, the catalyst particles were washed with water and acetone four times and shaken vigorously. The catalyst was dried at room temperature and re-used in the next reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Pd @ KIT-5 catalysts Identification of Pd @ KIT-5 catalysts using infrared spectroscopy The FT-IR spectra of all samples are shown in Fig. 1 . The bands at 471 and 802 cm−1 are related to the symmetric and asymmetric bending frequencies of Si-O, respectively, and the peaks at 1108 cm−1 are associated with the Si-O-Si stretching vibration. The wide band at 3436 cm−1 can be attributed to the O-H stretching frequencies in silanol groups [37,38]. A closer look at the Fig. 1 indicates by increasing the calcination temperature, an increase in Si-O-Si stretching band at 1108 cm−1 was observed. Also, an increase in O-H stretching vibration in 3400-3500 cm−1 region was occurred by increasing in calcination temperature. These observation may be related to depolymerization of silica surface and formation of new silanol; groups at higher temperatures. This finding is agreement with previous finding dealing with instability of 4-fold rings in the silica structures in elevated temperatures [39–41]. According to Falcaro et al. report, this observation indicates at higher temperatures 4-fold rings rearrange to less strained structures [41]. XRD patterns To confirm mesoporous and symmetrical structure of KIT-5 and Pd supported KIT-5 samples, low angle XRD analysis (2Ɵ = 0.5-10°) was conducted. As shown in Fig. 2 , the XRD pattern correlated to the pure KIT-5 shows an characteristic peak in the range of 2θ=0.5 to 1° and some peaks with low intensity in the range of 2θ=1.5 to 2 ° that are related to the characteristic planes (111), (200) and (220) in the cubic structure with Fm3m symmetry [42,43] . The decrease in the peak intensity compared to the pristine sample can be attributed to the successful metal loading on the silica substrate. The peak intensity of (111) plane in the catalysts Pd10% @ KIT-5/150 and Pd10% @ KIT-5/700 are much lower than the other catalysts, which may be concluded that while at 150 °C the mesoporous structure has not been constructed, at the 700 °C some walls are destroyed at higher calcination temperature. Fig. 3 shows the high angle XRD patterns of Pd @ KIT-5 catalysts. The broad peak in the range of 2θ = 15-30 ° are associated with amorphous silica [18]; the Pd peaks have appeared with different intensities in each catalyst, so that the catalysts calcined at higher temperatures show higher intensities. As the calcination temperature increases, the catalyst becomes more regular and crystalline, evident in the Pd10% @ KIT-5/700 XRD pattern. The peaks related to (111), (200), (220), (311), (422) planes can be assigned to palladium metal, all of which appeared for Pd10% @ KIT-5/700 catalyst, but in Pd10% @ KIT-5/150 XRD pattern these peaks are not recognizable. According to Scherrer's equation, the particle size of samples calculated 6.9, 15.8, and 32.7 nm for the Pd10%@KIT-5/350, Pd10%@KIT-5/550, and Pd10%@KIT-5/700 samples, respectively. Accordingly, the more activity of Pd10%@KIT-5/350 sample can be related to its lower particle sizes. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption data, including specific surface area, pore size distribution and pore surface, are given in Table 1 . As shown in the table, the surface area obtained for KIT-5 is 360 m2 / g, and the total pore volume is 0.259 cm3 / g, but when the Pd metal is placed on the silica support, the surface area and pore volume decreased, indicating that the metal is well placed inside the cavities. The remarkable point is the very low surface area of the Pd10% @ KIT-5/700 catalyst, which can be attributed to the high calcination temperature of the catalyst where, the walls and cavities of the support are destroyed at 700 °C. According to Fig. 4 , the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm for KIT-5 is of type IV isotherm, which has a high capillary nitrogen condensation at high relative pressures and an H2 hysteresis loop indicating that the pores are cage-type [19–21]. For Pd5% @ KIT-5/350 and Pd10% @ KIT-5/350 catalysts, the type IV isotherm is obtained and H2 hysteresis loop indicates that the structure of KIT-5 is preserved in the catalysts. However, in the Pd10% catalyst @ KIT-5/700, the shape is out of the obtained shape for the KIT-5 support, indicating that the catalyst walls have been destroyed. The average of pore size (BJH) after Pd metal stabilization on KIT-5 substrate for Pd5% @ KIT-5/350 and Pd10% @ KIT-5/350 catalysts has not changed and due to the decrease of surface area in both catalysts compared to KIT-5, it can be interpreted that the stabilization of Pd metal has been done successfully. However, in the Pd10% @ KIT-5/700 catalyst, the size distribution of the pores has been reduced to 1.21. Due to the high calcination temperature of the catalyst, where the walls and cavities have been destroyed (Fig. 5 ). The morphology of the samples KIT-5 (a), Pd10% @ KIT-5/350 (b) and Pd10% @ KIT-5/700 (c) was examined by scanning electron microscopy shown in Fig. 6 . The silica support KIT-5 is composed of small, irregularly porous and uniform particles with a smooth surface. After the deposition of Pd metal, this porous structure is preserved, while in the Pd10 @ KIT-5/700 catalyst. The porous structure is destroyed, and the walls are destroyed (Fig. 6c). The TEM images Pd10%@KIT-5/350 catalyst where the Pd was found to disperse on the SiO2 matrix and are severely aggregated. X-ray energy diffraction spectroscopy was used to confirm Pd metal's presence and determine the elements that make up the silica support. In Fig. 7 , EDS diagrams for Pd10% @ KIT-5/550 and Pd10% @ KIT-5/700 are shown. The presence of Pd peaks indicates that the Pd metal was successfully loaded onto the KIT-5 support. The sharp peaks for Si and O in all catalysts and KIT-5 indicate the existence of silica support. Also, the presence of Cl peaks for Pd10% @ KIT-5/350 catalyst is due to the use of PdCl2 salt, which despite the calcination of the catalyst at 350°C, Cl has not been removed from the catalyst structure, but for Pd10% @ KIT- catalysts. 5/550 and Pd10% @ KIT-5/700. The corresponding peak to Cl has been removed. The content of Pd in catalysts was determined using ICP analysis and the results for Pd in Pd2%@KIT-5/350, Pd5%@KIT-5/350, Pd10%@KIT-5/150, 1Pd10%@KIT-5/350, Pd10%@KIT-5/550, and. Pd10%@KIT-5/700 catalysts found to be 4%, 3.9%, 8.6, 8.4%, 7.7%, and 5.6%, respectively. Evaluation of Pd @ KIT-5 Catalysts performance for In situ Hydrogenation Reaction Several parameters such as catalyst type, temperature, time, amount of phenol, and consumed sodium formate relative to catalyst were examined to optimize the reaction conditions for a higher phenol conversion percentage. Scheme 1 provides an overview of the hydrogenation reaction of phenol by different Pd10@ KIT catalysts under different conditions. At the first, the performance of six prepared catalysts supported on KIT-5 was evaluated for the reduction of phenol using sodium formate. For this purpose, a model reaction consisting of 0.1 g of phenol, 0.05 g of catalyst and 0.5 g of sodium formate in 10 mL of double distilled water was used in a 50 mL autoclave at 140°C for 6 h (Table 2 , entries 1–8). As depicted in Table 2, Pd10% @ KIT-5/350 catalyst has the highest phenol conversion percentage among all the prepared catalysts, while it has not shown good selectivity for cyclohexanone (entry 6). On the other hand, Pd10% @ KIT-5/700 catalyst has the highest selectivity for cyclohexanone production (entry 8). Also, comparing the results obtained from the study of Pd5% @ KIT-5/350 and Pd2% catalysts @ KIT-5/350 shows that the more deposition of Pd metal on the KIT-5 support, the less amount of phenol hydrogenation (entries 3-4). One experiment without catalyst and one reaction with pure support as control reactions were performed for better describing and understanding the results. Due to the high importance of converting phenol to cyclohexanone and cyclohexanol, Pd10% catalyst @ KIT-5/350, which has a higher conversion rate among all catalysts, was selected as the best catalyst. To optimize the temperature, the model reaction was investigated at different temperatures. From the results, the optimal reaction temperature is 40°C, at which the phenol has a conversion above 99% (entry 14). Reaction temperature has a great effect on the rate and percentage of phenol conversion. With increasing temperature from 100 to 160°C, the percentage of phenol conversion decreases (entries 9-11), but the selectivity of cyclohexanone has increased, which can be attributed to thermodynamic constraints or removal of phenol from the catalyst surface or decrease of catalyst activity for hydrogen adsorption at high temperatures [44]. To better evaluate the capability of the prepared catalysts, the performance of two catalysts, Pd10% @ KIT-5/350 and Pd10% @ KIT-5/700 was compared at 40°C. Pd10% @ KIT-5/700 catalyst has no activity at this temperature (entry 17). To find the optimal reaction time, the model reaction was conducted at different times at 40 °C, the results are summarized in Table 3 . According to the findings, the hydrogenation reaction of phenol is completed within 6 h. Phenol conversion and selectivity can be shown in Scheme 2. The hydrogenation reaction of phenol is fast, and cyclohexanone is produced as the predominant product. Still, when the reaction time changes from 4 h to 6 h, cyclohexanone is slowly converted to cyclohexanol. Cyclohexanone and cyclohexanol were detected by GC during the progress of the reaction, but 1-hydroxy cyclohexene was not observed on the chromatogram. Hydroxy cyclohexene is an intermediate that is easily and very rapidly converted to cyclohexanone, and the longer the reaction time, the more cyclohexanol is produced along the d path. According to the results in Table 3, when the reaction is performed within 16 h, 70% of cyclohexanol is produced. Then, the amounts of phenol and sodium formate were optimized for 0.05 g of catalyst, the results of which are given in Table 4 . The optimum value specified for complete phenol conversion is 0.1 g of the initial phenol compared to 0.05 g of the catalyst, in which the phenol conversion is complete. As the amount of primary phenol increased, the conversion percentage decreased (Table 4, entries 1–5). On the other hand, at high levels of primary phenol, only cyclohexanone was produced, which indicates that the amount of hydrogen was not sufficient for complete hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanol. Sodium formate as a source of hydrogen during the hydrogenation of phenols is another crucial aspect of the reaction optimization process. According to the results (Table 4, entries 6–8), the lower the hydrogen in the environment, the more cyclohexanone is produced as the dominant product. For example, for 0.1 g of phenol, when 0.2 g of sodium formate is used, only 15% of the phenol is hydrogenated, and cyclohexanone is the only product produced because hydrogen is low in the medium and the phenol is reduced to only cyclohexanone. One of the major advantages of heterogeneous catalysts is their separation at the end of each reaction and its recyclability. Therefore, the stability of the Pd10% @ KIT-5/350 catalyst in 4 consecutive cycles was investigated. According to Fig. 8 , after using the catalyst in 4 reaction cycles, the percentage of phenol conversion has decreased from 99 to 60%. For more evaluation to find the reasons for the deactivation of Pd10%@KIT-5/350 catalyst, a series of experiments were conducted. For this purpose, two experiment including ICP analysis after hot filtration of the reaction mixture in the half-reaction time and ATR analysis of catalyst before and after reaction to the evaluation of CO adsorption and deactivation was achieved. While ICP analysis confirmed presence of Pd nanoparticles leached to the reaction mixture, ATR analysis also detected the presence of CO in the range 1700-2300 cm-1 indicating poisoning of catalyst surface (See Fig. 9 ). According to Lefferts et al., only 0.2% formic acid decomposition in the dehydration pathway (instead of dehydrogenation path) can cover a catalyst with about 3% Pd loading [45,46]. 3.2 Identification of products produced from in situ hydrogenation reaction of phenol using Pd10% catalyst @ KIT-5/350 Hydrogenation of phenol was performed in the presence of Pd10% @ KIT-5/350 catalyst using sodium formate as a source of hydrogen in an aqueous medium. Cyclohexanone and cyclohexanol were identified as the products of phenol hydrogenation by GC-MASS. In Figs. 10 and 11 , the mass spectra of cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone can be seen, respectively. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, Pd2%@KIT-5/350, Pd5%@KIT-5/350, Pd10%@KIT-5/150, Pd10%@KIT-5/350, Pd10%@KIT-5/550, Pd10%@KIT-5/700 catalysts were prepared for in situ reductions of phenols in the presence of sodium formate as the hydrogen source. The results showed that the calcination temperature and the amount of Pd deposition on the KIT-5 support had a significant effect on catalytic performance. The Pd10%@KIT-5/350 catalyst was selected as the best catalyst because of the highest phenol conversion. The amount of 0.05 g of catalyst at 40°C during 6 h, showed the conversion ability of phenol (0.1 g) to cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone with an efficiency of over 99%. The amount of sodium formate was also optimized for the reaction, which showed that the higher the ratio of sodium formate to phenol, the lower the selectivity of cyclohexanone to cyclohexanol. coredata.dc:description: In this research, in situ hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanone and cyclohexanol mixture (KA oil) in aqueous medium using sodium formate as the hydrogen source is studied by using Pd catalysts supported on mesoporous KIT-5. The effect of calcination temprature of catalysts as well as reaction temperature, time, catalyst types, the amount of initial phenol and sodium formate, which are the most effective factors for phenol conversion, were investigated and the optimum values are reported. The Pd10%@KIT-5/350 catalyst (calcined at 350°C) exhibited as the most effective catalyst. Using this catalyst, the best results were gained at 40°C and a reaction time of 6 h, the optimal ratio of phenol: catalyst 0.1:0.05 with 0.5 g sodium formate. Under these conditions, 99% phenol conversion was obtained. Pd10%@KIT-5/350 as the most effective catalyst was successfully regenerated by centrifugation and filtration after reaction and reused in four consecutive cycles. The results showed that the calcination temperature in the preparation of Pd@KIT-5 catalysts has an important role in the hydrogenation reaction of phenol. The studies in this research showed that the higher the calcination temperature, the lower the percentage of phenol conversion, but the selectivity of the catalyst for the production of cyclohexanone increases.
coredata.dc:title: In situ hydrogenation of phenol using sodium formate in an aqueous medium on unmodified palladium catalysts supported on KIT-5: Investigation of calcination temperature effect
